Glee Club Practices
Tunes For First Concert
In its preparations for the coming season, the Johns Hopkins
Glee Club has been practicing several selections.
These include Shenandoah, a
traditional chanty, freely arranged by Marshall Bartholomew; and
The Lord's Prayer, music by Albert
Hay Molotte and arranged by Carl
Deis.
Tuesday night rehearsals are
held for first and second tenors;
Thursday night rehearsals, for first
and second bass voices.
The first Music Club concert is
scheduled for the early part of December.

'Stormers To Hold Rally
In Playshop Thursday
The annual Barnstormer's rally
will be held on Thursday evening,
October 22, in the Playshop. The
entire 'student body is invited to
attend.
There will be plenty of talks,
,skits, and fun. John E. Desch, the
'Stormers new coach will be introduced, and Barnstormer comedians
will perform.
All students interested in any
branch of dramatics work are urged to attend the rally.

Tuesday, October 20, 1936

Eddy On .Russia
.Dr. Sherwood Eddy's all too brief
address in Maryland Hall last Thursday should emphasize, more than ever
belore, the fact that, whether friend
or foe, all must realize the significance of what is going on in Russia
today. And that realization can be
brought about only by adopting a
sympathetic attitude toward Russia.
The importance of the economic and
social revolution undertaken by the
Soviets must not be underestimated.
,it is, certainly, "one of the boldest
experiments in the history of civilization," and much a the future of
civilization depends upon the results
ef that experiment.
The "Y" should be congratulated
for bringing Dr. Eddy to the Hopkins
during the assembly hour. Perhaps
this action will be an inspiration to
tne Student Council.

Vs.
Thursday night a meeting was held
In New York City. it was called by
various liberal groups of the metropons as a mass protest against the
reelection to the State Senate of one
John J. MeNaboe. Mr. McNaboe, it
seems, has built up for himself quite
a reputation for Americanism.
He has, among other things, advocated Leachers' oath bills; he has requested and received from the State
Senate $1.5,000 for the investigation of
"unarnerican activities;" he has encouraged the legislation of numerous
acts restricting education freedom.
Another American was in New
York Friday evening--one Isaiah
Bowman, president of an enlightened
University. This one had other ideas
on academic freedom. Among the remarks which he made on teachers'
bilis were the following:
"I wish you could see this oath
movement as a symptom with
broadest implications," he said.
"Universities have made their
contributions to the life of their
times, and also to the corpus of
useful knowledge and to the philosophy of living, by having and
keeping that independence without which there can be no enduring vitality of thought.
"It is necessary to underscore
the need for alertness in reference to this movement and to
every other sign of invasion of
for
independence,

without independence good work
cannot be done in the fields of the
social sciences and humanities."

Addresses Given By Mr.

Hershner Cross, Aided By
Jerry Branower, Conducts
Meeting
About 150 freshmen attended a buffet supper presented by the Hopkins
Chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa,
,National Honorary Fraternity last
Friday night. The supper, held in Levering Hall, preceeded the night foot(ball game between Washington and
Johns Hopkins.. Several prominent
espeakers both of the student body and
of the faculty addressed the group.
Bowman Sends Greetings
Hershner Cross, president of the
Oi.udent Council, aided by Jerry Branuwer, served as Master of Ceremonies.
e.rreetings to the Freshman class from
iL Isaiah Bowman, who w.,
pot able to come in person because of
fa previous dinner engagement in
4:,lew York, were read by 13ranower.
president Bowman said, in short, "I
wish to express my cordial greetings
and good wishes to the entering class
and the hope that I may soon be able
,10 greet it in person."
Principles Of 0. D. K.
Dr. Mark Howard Secrist, Geology
(Instructor at the Hopkins, addressed
the group next, setting forth three
primary principles of the O.D.K. A.
,oluing to Dr. Secrist, they are recognition of men who are active in one
or more activities on the campus, a
fnethod for bringing such men together so that they may serve the
institution as a unit, anti a means of
linking the student body and the
faculty.
Dr. Thomas Hubbard of the Engineering School, the next speaker,
.turther developed the concepts set
forth by Dr. Secrist. He expressed the
;belief that O.D.K. performs two basic services: one to the University, the
Other to individuals of the student
body. He explained that the five
stars on the Society's pin represented:
athletics, forensics, publications, educational entertainment, and scholarship. Men who possess a high degree
of ability in one or more of .those
itields get their reward in recognition
O.D.K.
Here Doctor Hubbard cited the
amusing parable of the Order of the
Garter, when, in days of old, men
fought for the privilege of having a
lady give him her garter. This honor
society recognizes the contribution of
itune, energy and ambition of those
who have left Hopkins as good as, or
(better than, when they entered it.
Each student should try just a little
harder to fulfill the requireents of
O.D.K. and, even if all do not reach
membership, at least O.D.K. served as
iin incentive to greater heights, a fact
which, in itself, justifies its existence.
Invited To Rally
Leaders of student activities were
present and Martin Levine, president
pf the Barnstormers, issued a hearty
nvitation to all to attend the Barnstormers' rally at the Playshop next
;Mursday.
The meeting was climaxed by the
singing of "Dear Old Johnny Hopkins" and "On the Line" under the
leadership of Holt Maulsby, chairman
of the Student Activities Committee,
and shortly afterwards the group adjourned to the football field.

Pindar will continue the great reputation of the scholarly Philhellens. It
is the work of an archaeologist, philospher, litterateur--and humanist. It
will be welcomed by all students of
the great Greek poet; by all lovers of
poetry.
Professor .mobinson's Pindar is a
brilliant critique of the Theban poet.
It is a work that shows the influence
of Pindar on the literature of many
lands and ages. The professor is a
forceful apologist and he establishes
the fact that Pindar was not bare of
thought, philosophy, and human interest, as some have maintained. "It is
good," quotes Professor Robinson
from Fame!!, "to have lived long with
Pindar."

the way in which Mexico's revolutionary governments have been slowly

Our sympathies to those boys who
were unfortunate enough to have

How many of you noticed the female cheerleader of the Washington
cheering squad? And incidentally
tiTere were more women than men in
the visiting stands.
* * * *
"Dena" Traggis seemed to he awfully close to the earth when he stood
along side the big Washington men
Incidentally it was 'Trag" who made
the first tackle after he got into the
game.
The Washington team went into a
puddle, I mean huddle, fifteen yards
behind the line of scrimmage. I guess
the shore school has no cross country
team, so the football squad has to
double up.

Tom Ellis says "those boys were
plenty big" and if he says so we can
;take his word fo it.

louder and snappier. Come on, frosh,
ilearn those yells. And seniors needn't
ibe too dignified, even when with a
woman, to make some use of their
lungs.

Glee Club Practices
Tunes For First Concert
In its preparations for the coming season, the Johns Hopkins
Glee Club has been practicing several selections.
These include Shenandoah, a
traditional chanty, freely arranged by Marshall Bartholomew; and
The Lord's Prayer, music by Albert
Hay Molotte and arranged by Carl
Deis.
Tuesday night rehearsals are
held for first and second tenors;
Thursday night rehearsals, for first
and second bass voices.
The first Music Club concert is
scheduled for the early part of December.

'Stormers To Hold Rally
In Playshop Thursday
The annual Barnstormer's rally
will be held on Thursday evening,
October 22, in the Playshop. The
entire 'student body is invited to
attend.
There will be plenty of talks,
,skits, and fun. John E. Desch, the
'Stormers new coach will be introduced, and Barnstormer comedians
will perform.
All students interested in any
branch of dramatics work are urged to attend the rally.

Eddy On .Russia
.Dr. Sherwood Eddy's all too brief
address in Maryland Hall last Thursday should emphasize, more than ever
belore, the fact that, whether friend
or foe, all must realize the significance of what is going on in Russia
today. And that realization can be
brought about only by adopting a
sympathetic attitude toward Russia.
The importance of the economic and
social revolution undertaken by the
Soviets must not be underestimated.
,it is, certainly, "one of the boldest
experiments in the history of civilization," and much a the future of
civilization depends upon the results
ef that experiment.
The "Y" should be congratulated
for bringing Dr. Eddy to the Hopkins
during the assembly hour. Perhaps
this action will be an inspiration to
tne Student Council.

Thursday night a meeting was held
In New York City. it was called by
various liberal groups of the metropons as a mass protest against the
reelection to the State Senate of one
John J. MeNaboe. Mr. McNaboe, it
seems, has built up for himself quite
a reputation for Americanism.
He has, among other things, advocated Leachers' oath bills; he has requested and received from the State
Senate $1.5,000 for the investigation of
"unarnerican activities;" he has encouraged the legislation of numerous
acts restricting education freedom.
Another American was in New
York Friday evening--one Isaiah
Bowman, president of an enlightened
University. This one had other ideas
on academic freedom. Among the remarks which he made on teachers'
bilis were the following:
"I wish you could see this oath
movement as a symptom with
broadest implications," he said.
"Universities have made their
contributions to the life of their
times, and also to the corpus of
useful knowledge and to the philosophy of living, by having and
keeping that independence without which there can be no enduring vitality of thought.
"It is necessary to underscore
the need for alertness in reference to this movement and to
every other sign of invasion of
for

without independence good work
cannot be done in the fields of the
social sciences and humanities."

A few remarks of historical interest are here in order. Herbert
Hoover won the student poll in
1932. Albert Ritchie won the gubernatorial poll of the faculty in
1934. The mere fact that both of
tnese men were ultimately defeated is of little consequence.
What is more important is this:
in 1932 Hopkins sentiment chose
a good old-fashioned, "do-nothing" Republican; two years later
it selected a consei vative Democratid reformer. Last spring at
a preliminary student poll of the
Campus President Roosevelt was
chosen to succeed nimself.
The change of opinion is interesting. The results of today's poll
will probably agree with last
Spring's. If it does, it would be an
interesting study for some historian or sociologist to attempt to
explain why undergraduate Hopkins evolved as it did from reaction to liberalism.

Given By O.D.K.
To Freshmen
Addresses Given By Mr.
Thomas Hubbard And Dr.
Mark Secrist

See Football Game
Hershner Cross, Aided By
Jerry Branower, Conducts
Meeting
About 150 freshmen attended a buffet supper presented by the Hopkins
Chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa,
,National Honorary Fraternity last
Friday night. The supper, held in Levering Hall, preceeded the night foot(ball game between Washington and
Johns Hopkins.. Several prominent
espeakers both of the student body and
of the faculty addressed the group.
Bowman Sends Greetings
Hershner Cross, president of the
Oi.udent Council, aided by Jerry Branuwer, served as Master of Ceremonies.
e.rreetings to the Freshman class from
iL Isaiah Bowman, who w.,
pot able to come in person because of
fa previous dinner engagement in
4:,lew York, were read by 13ranower.
president Bowman said, in short, "I
wish to express my cordial greetings
and good wishes to the entering class
and the hope that I may soon be able
,10 greet it in person."
Principles Of 0. D. K.
Dr. Mark Howard Secrist, Geology
(Instructor at the Hopkins, addressed
the group next, setting forth three
primary principles of the O.D.K. A.
,oluing to Dr. Secrist, they are recognition of men who are active in one
or more activities on the campus, a
fnethod for bringing such men together so that they may serve the
institution as a unit, anti a means of
linking the student body and the
faculty.
Dr. Thomas Hubbard of the Engineering School, the next speaker,
.turther developed the concepts set
forth by Dr. Secrist. He expressed the
;belief that O.D.K. performs two basic services: one to the University, the
Other to individuals of the student
body. He explained that the five
stars on the Society's pin represented:
athletics, forensics, publications, educational entertainment, and scholarship. Men who possess a high degree
of ability in one or more of .those
itields get their reward in recognition
O.D.K.
Here Doctor Hubbard cited the
amusing parable of the Order of the
Garter, when, in days of old, men
fought for the privilege of having a
lady give him her garter. This honor
society recognizes the contribution of
itune, energy and ambition of those
who have left Hopkins as good as, or
(better than, when they entered it.
Each student should try just a little
harder to fulfill the requireents of
O.D.K. and, even if all do not reach
membership, at least O.D.K. served as
iin incentive to greater heights, a fact
which, in itself, justifies its existence.
Invited To Rally
Leaders of student activities were
present and Martin Levine, president
pf the Barnstormers, issued a hearty
nvitation to all to attend the Barnstormers' rally at the Playshop next
;Mursday.
The meeting was climaxed by the
singing of "Dear Old Johnny Hopkins" and "On the Line" under the
leadership of Holt Maulsby, chairman
of the Student Activities Committee,
and shortly afterwards the group adjourned to the football field.

can have the ear on Hellas any time

Pindar will continue the great reputation of the scholarly Philhellens. It
is the work of an archaeologist, philospher, litterateur--and humanist. It
will be welcomed by all students of
the great Greek poet; by all lovers of
poetry.
Professor .mobinson's Pindar is a
brilliant critique of the Theban poet.
It is a work that shows the influence
of Pindar on the literature of many
lands and ages. The professor is a
forceful apologist and he establishes
the fact that Pindar was not bare of
thought, philosophy, and human interest, as some have maintained. "It is
good," quotes Professor Robinson
from Fame!!, "to have lived long with
Pindar."

How many of you noticed the female cheerleader of the Washington
cheering squad? And incidentally
tiTere were more women than men in
the visiting stands.

"Dena" Traggis seemed to he awfully close to the earth when he stood
along side the big Washington men
Incidentally it was 'Trag" who made
the first tackle after he got into the
game.
The Washington team went into a
puddle, I mean huddle, fifteen yards
behind the line of scrimmage. I guess
the shore school has no cross country
team, so the football squad has to
double up.

Tom Ellis says "those boys were
plenty big" and if he says so we can
;take his word fo it.
The cheering could have been a lot
louder and snappier. Come on, frosh,
ilearn those yells. And seniors needn't
ibe too dignified, even when with a
woman, to make some use of their
lungs.
